qas.question: What did Descartes believe about vacuums in nature?

answers.text: that a vacuum does not occur in nature

qas.question: Whose work with metaphysics would come to define the notion of empty space?
What philosophy combined with Descartes to push quantum activity in the 20th century?

plausible_answers.text: nothing–everything dichotomy of void and atom

qas.question: What dichotomy did Descartes center his theory around?
What position did Plato agree with?
Where did Plato believe a vaccuum did not occur?
What philosophy was behind Plato's understanding of a vacuum?

plausible_answers.text: the philosophically modern notion of empty space as a quantified extension of volume

qas.question: What did Plato's discoveries about atomism come to define about empty space?

context: Almost two thousand years after Plato, René Descartes also proposed a geometrically based alternative theory of atomism, without the problematic <b3_0>nothing–everything dichotomy of void and atom<b3_0/>. Although <a1_0>Descartes<a1_0/> agreed with <b4_0>the contemporary position<b4_0/>, <a0_0>that a vacuum does not occur <b5_0>in nature<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the success of his namesake coordinate system and more implicitly, the spatial–corporeal component of his metaphysics would come to define <b7_0>the philosophically modern notion of empty space as a quantified extension of volume<b7_0/>. By the ancient definition however, directional information and magnitude were conceptually distinct. With the acquiescence of <a2_0><b6_0>Cartesian mechanical philosophy<b6_0/><a2_0/> to the "brute fact" of action at a distance, and at length, its successful reification by force fields and ever more sophisticated geometric structure, the anachronism of empty space widened until "a seething ferment" of quantum activity in the 20th century filled the vacuum with a virtual pleroma.
